text: my name is Matt ajisen and I'm the
puppet designer and puppetry supervisor
for compulsion at the public theater
there's characters in in the world like
Anne Frank who are so iconic and so
powerful that you just say that person's
name like you say Anne Frank and you
already have an image in your head of
what that person looks like and I think
especially in terms of this production
when I see an actor on stage no matter
how good they are I know at the end of
the day they're going to change their
clothes and go home but Anne Frank in
this production never changes her
clothes and never goes home she's always
purely Anne Frank and I think there's
something just innately powerful about
that and pure about that for me this was
a real challenge because I'm used to
designing a little puppets that are much
more abstract and much more kind of
emotionally representative of the
character I spend a lot of time around
old objects and antiques and I'd like to
be around objects that people have used
and put in put residue on and i feel
when i create puppets i usually take
objects that have a history that you can
see their marks or they're used or
they're worn and that tells a story and
then when i put that next to another
object that tells another story so just
by the puppets standing there there's
already kind of a history of where this
puppets been from and so I kind of
carried that over into how to design
these puppets which are much more very
much literal figures and they have hair
well they don't have hair but they're
they're real representations of people
